title: two album leaves from a landscape album
text: Li Liu-fang was born in Chia-ting just north of Shanghai in 1575. In 1606 he passed the Chu-jen degree but by 1622, he gave up all thoughts of government service and turned to paintings and poetry. A friend of Tung Chi-ch'ang, he was included among the group known as the "Nine Friends of Painting." Peers in this group included Shao Mi, Cheng Chia-sui, Wang Shih-min, Wang Chien, and Tung Ch'i-ch'ang himself. Li painted most successfully in small formats, playing with ink and trying to transmit the creative essence of certain old masters like Wu chen rather than their formal patterns. Most of his works seem improvised mood sketches executed with fresh spontaneity. This album contains examples of Li's early dry linear style with insubstantial compositions as well as his later inkier style with its rich, wet brush modulation.
description:
two album leaves mounted on boards and matted; left is calligraphic; right is landscape with a group of four trees in center in slightly sloped landscape

from accordion-style album, wood covers; eight images, alternating with text, single page of text at end
